forecast.rationale: Signals point toward Ouattara being the RHDP’s preferred nominee, but timing is the key. These are strong elite cues but do not yet meet the resolution criterion that he himself declare before June 1. Historically, Ouattara declared relatively close to the election (e.g., 2020 declaration in early August for an October vote), and incumbents sometimes delay formal entry to preserve leverage over internal negotiations and coalition-building. With roughly one month left, the status quo (no personal declaration) slightly dominates absent evidence of a scheduled May RHDP congress or set-piece announcement. Reasons the probability is not higher: no personal on-the-record declaration so far; no widely reported date for a May party congress/nomination; past precedent of later declarations. Reasons it is not lower: he is eligible under the 2016 constitutional framework; senior ministers repeatedly assert he will be the candidate; party discipline and incumbency advantages make an eventual run plausible; declaring in May would consolidate the party and shape the field. What would move me up: credible reports of an RHDP extraordinary congress or national council meeting scheduled in May with a candidate nomination on the agenda; announcements of a presidential address or large rally billed as a “major declaration.” What would move me down: continued silence into mid-May; leaks about RHDP vetting alternate standard-bearers; signs of health or intra-party issues prompting delay or reconsideration.
